titles.title: A Dataset for Metaphor Detection in Early Medieval Hebrew Poetry
FigureOut - Automatic Detection of Metaphors in Hebrew Across the Eras

descriptions.description: The corpus of late antique and medieval Hebrew is vast and represents a crucial linguistic and cultural bridge between Biblical and modern Hebrew. Poetry is prominent in texts from these time periods and one of its characteristics is the use of metaphor. Distinguishing figurative and literal words or phrases is a major task for scholars in the Humanities, especially in the fields of literature, linguistics, and hermeneutics. We present a new, challenging dataset of early medieval Hebrew poetry with expert annotations of metaphors with baseline results. The dataset contains 180 labeled texts, 7,000 sentences, and 45,000 words, with 15% of the words being metaphors. Inter-annotator agreement measured by Cohen's kappa is 0.618 (considered substantial).

Three language models were used: BEREL (pre-trained on 220 million words of medieval texts), AlephBERT (pre-trained on 2 billion words of modern Hebrew), and AlephBERT Adapted (trained on 2 billion words of modern Hebrew plus 10 million words of medieval texts from Project Ben-Yehuda and the Piyyut dataset). Fine-tuning for metaphor detection was performed using tokenizers with metaphor/not-a-metaphor classification. Language model adaptation involved training on additional prose and poetic medieval texts.

Poster presented at Digital Humanities 2023: Collaboration as Opportunity (DH2023), Graz, Austria, July 10-14, 2023. The poster introduces a new, challenging dataset in Hebrew and seeks to extend automatic metaphor detection capabilities in pre-modern Hebrew.
Project Ben-Yehuda is a volunteer-based online library of free Hebrew literature used as a source for medieval texts in the adapted language model training.

ast.title: A Dataset for Metaphor Detection in Early Medieval Hebrew Poetry
ast.introduction: The corpus of late antique and medieval Hebrew is vast and represents a crucial linguistic and cultural bridge between Biblical and modern Hebrew. Poetry is prominent in texts from these time periods and one of its characteristics is the use of metaphor. Distinguishing figurative and literal words or phrases is a major task for scholars in the Humanities, especially in the fields of literature, linguistics, and hermeneutics. We present a new, challenging dataset of early medieval Hebrew poetry with expert annotations of metaphors with baseline results.
ast.methods: Three language models were evaluated: BEREL (pre-trained on 220 million words of medieval Hebrew texts), AlephBERT (pre-trained on 2 billion words of modern Hebrew), and AlephBERT Adapted (trained on 2 billion modern Hebrew words plus 10 million additional medieval words from Project Ben-Yehuda and the Piyyut dataset). Two approaches were tested: fine-tuning for metaphor detection using pre-trained and adapted language models with tokenizers, and language model adaptation by training on additional prose and poetic medieval texts. The models classify words as metaphor or not-a-metaphor.
ast.results: The dataset consists of early medieval Hebrew poems with 180 labeled texts, 7,000 sentences, and 45,000 words. Fifteen percent of the words are metaphors. Inter-annotator agreement achieved a Cohen's kappa of 0.618, considered substantial. Model performance on the test set showed: AlephBERT achieved an F1 score of 44.404, BEREL achieved 48.3, and AlephBERT Adapted achieved 46.56. BEREL, pre-trained on medieval texts, shows the best results. AlephBERT is outperformed by AlephBERT Adapted.
ast.conclusions: BEREL, the language model pre-trained specifically on medieval Hebrew texts, achieved the highest performance for metaphor detection in early medieval Hebrew poetry. The adapted version of AlephBERT, which combined modern and medieval training data, outperformed the base AlephBERT model, demonstrating the value of domain adaptation.
ast.acknowledgements: Project Ben-Yehuda provided volunteer-based online library resources of free Hebrew literature. The dataset includes examples from a medieval Hebrew poem from the Worms Prayerbook, Germany, 13th Century, from The National Library of Israel 'Ktiv' Project.

contentArray.title1: A Dataset for Metaphor Detection in Early Medieval Hebrew Poetry. The corpus of late antique and medieval Hebrew is vast and represents a crucial linguistic and cultural bridge between Biblical and modern Hebrew. Poetry is prominent in texts from these time periods and one of its characteristics is the use of metaphor.
contentArray.title2: The Dataset: Early medieval Hebrew poems. 180 labeled texts, 7,000 sentences, 45,000 words. 15% of the words are metaphors. Example metaphors with Hebrew, English, and meaning provided in table format showing phrases like 'We drowned in decrees, like sea washed' (meaning: There are too many decrees), 'Ignite a soul, fire a candle' (meaning: Create a soul), 'Until the tenth generation they did not bear fruit' (meaning: For ten generations, they did no good deeds).
contentArray.title3: Inter Annotator Agreement: Inter-annotator agreement evaluates how consistently different annotators label data for NLP research (measured in Cohen's kappa). The score for our dataset is 0.618 (considered substantial).
contentArray.title4: Methods: Two approaches shown - Fine-tuning for metaphor detection using Pre-trained/Adapted Language Model with Tokenizer classifying as Metaphor/Not a Metaphor. LM adaptation showing Pre-trained Language Model with Hebrew text input, Tokenizer processing, and training on additional prose and poetic medieval texts from Project Ben-Yehuda and Piyyut dataset. Language models table shows BEREL (220 Million words, Medieval), AlephBERT (2 Billion words, Modern), AlephBERT Adapted (2 Billion + 10 Million words, Modern + Medieval).
contentArray.title5: Results: F1 Score on test set shows AlephBERT: 44.404, BEREL: 48.3, AlephBERT - adapted: 46.56. AlephBERT is outperformed by AlephBERT Adapted. BEREL, pre-trained on medieval texts, shows the best results. Error Analysis shows example with Hebrew text and expert explanation: The child is a non-metaphorical epithet for Isaac. 'Scent' is a metonymic term for 'sacrifice'.

tableCaption.caption2: Three-column table showing Hebrew text, English translation, and Meaning. Row 1: Hebrew 'טבענו בגזרות, כשטופי ים', English 'We drowned in decrees, like sea washed', Meaning 'There are too many decrees'. Row 2: Hebrew 'הצית נשמה ויבער נר', English 'Ignite a soul, fire a candle', Meaning 'Create a soul'. Row 3: Hebrew 'עד דור עשירי לא עשו פרי', English 'Until the tenth generation they did not bear fruit', Meaning 'For ten generations, they did no good deeds'.

Three-column table showing language model names, data size in words, and data type. BEREL: 220 Million words, Medieval. AlephBERT: 2 Billion words, Modern. AlephBERT Adapted: 2 Billion + 10 Million words, Modern + Medieval. Note indicates trained on additional prose and poetic medieval texts from Project Ben-Yehuda and Piyyut dataset.
